And they always try to justify it with "i'll carry" or "i'm smurfing" and "can't sup", sit down kid you're not carrying anything if you don't even have the mental capacity to pick Soraka and press W in bronze.

I remember enjoying this when it was implemented around 6.1 and Ezreal was by and far the best ad and every gameTIME FOR A TRUE DISPLAY OF SKILL TIME FOR A TRUE DISPLAY OF SKILL TIME FOR A TRUE DISPLAY OF SKILL TIME FOR A TRUE DISPLAY OF SKILL TIME FOR A TRUE DISPLAY OF SKILL TIME FOR A TRUE DISPLAY OF SK

Oh hey, I'm the original creator of this video! I posted here a while back to not much traction and didn't bother again because looking back I wasn't too satisfied with it^^^especiallythefirstpart but thank you for sharing it here! NA in 2016 was a teary ride.

So now that 2016 is drawing to a close I wanted to make a tribute to the scene's storyline over the year (and those preceding it!). I was really really amazed when [Monte came out with his parody lyrics](http://ggcmontecristo.tumblr.com/post/151829351167/i-asked-a-long-time-na-fan-about-league-of#notes) to "Miss American Pie", "NA's Apple Pie" and equally so when TBSkyen posted his [sung rendition of it](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vc8sztpxO34), so I decided to make a music video/montage of sorts set to the song!
Took about three days to put together, clips mostly taken from reddit, twitter various Riot vods, TSM and C9's Legends/Genesis shows, and a few other vids here and there. Some parts didn't come out as well as I'd like but to do the song justice, but I hope y'all enjoy this little thing.

WRITING.TITLE: To commemorate NA's 2016 run, I made an MV to TBSkyen's rendition of Monte's "NA's Apple Pie!"

WRITING.TEXT: I mean you're right I just thought it was interesting/cool how the update makes his sworn enemy the best possible target.

WRITING.TITLE: The Zed "rework" helped him achieve his in-lore goal!
WRITING.TEXT:
I was reading through some of the lores today with the universe update and was reminded of the fact that Zed has lets just say a bit of a *vendetta* against Jhin.
From [Jhin's lore](http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Jhin/Background): When they caught Jhin, young Zed marched forward to kill the cowering man, but Kusho held him back.
Zed, disturbed and haunted by the murder scenes he had witnessed, was unable to understand or accept this mercy, and it is said a resentment began to bloom in his heart.
"You know what that... thing is capable of." Then Zed leaned over the table, well within Shen's range - his neck intentionally exposed. "And you know that we are the only two people who can get close enough to stop him."
Shen remembered the first time he'd seen the body of someone killed by the infamous Khada Jhin. His skin prickled from the memory; his teeth clenched. Only his father had been strong enough to still believe a merciful justice could be served. Something in Shen had changed that day. Something in Zed had broken.
There was still no sign of Zed. It was disappointing. Very disappointing. He certainly must have sought out his former friend. It was likely Zed was hiding, watching. Jhin needed to be careful.
Basically Zed was traumatised by Jhin's actions, swore to kill the guy and is in fact actively hunting him.
Now, the recent "rework" gave Zed incentive to kill targets with high AD. Due to his passive, Jhin is capable of hitting the highest AD in the game. Indeed, I'm pretty sure the "new Zed" was advertised as being a Jhin counter. I see what you did there Riot.

WRITING.TITLE: When Dynamic Queue was announced, a lot of Redditors declared they wouldn't play ranked this season. Did anyone follow through with that?
WRITING.TEXT: Just curious, now that the season is ending. I recall a lot of dissent over DQ (myself included) and many stating that they wouldn't play ranked or even quit the game altogether because Riot had "ruined it" and I'm wondering if that held through for anyone here or if Riot's attempts and remedying the issues and reaching out to the community brought people back. Did y'all play more or less ranked this year than in previous years?

Also he has a really sexy laugh
Relevant flair.

Frosk is also - if you see her post on Reddit (/u/thatchinesefangirl) and elsewhere, very eagerly open to criticism and takes that which is given to her onboard. She may still be subpar to several viewers but it's very obvious she had made an effort to improve and is continuing to do so. LS is very much the same analyst he was 2 years ago and does not take to criticism well - he often just goes on saying the same thing without considering what has been put to him (as seen with him repeating things after Alex Ich disagreed AND appeared to be right based on what happened in game). Goes a long way toward the perception of a person.

WRITING.TITLE: TIL Gnar, Azir, Kalista Rek'sai - 4 champs who've been under recent fire for overloaded kits - were all released consecutively.
WRITING.TEXT:
Or rather, today I remembered :P.
Been seeing a lot of discussion in the community recently about how all four of the above champions have extremely powerful kits that cause them to dominate the meta and crowd out other champs in their roles if their numbers are even remotely decent (and often refuse to fall off even when they're nerfed because of the utility of their kits) and it made me think "huh weren't they all released in 2014" and then I realised all four were released within months of each other. Makes me wonder just what Riot was thinking with their design philosophy at the time and how it's shaped their philosophies going forward.

while i agree her comments can usually be pretty left-field i thought the drake comment was fine in the context of the series and all three casters previous commentary on it - RNG was playing reactive and passive all series up until that point and had been called out on it so the comment sounded more like an extension of that (ie: "yes they got mountain drake but it's not worth much if they keep playing like they have been") and just imo it would have been more out of place to say "i'm interested to see what proactive things they do with it!" when in context you wouldn't expect them to be proactive just based on how they'd been playing :p. you are right she probably could have segued that into a comment about how they could take advantage of their comp to start being proactive or smth though.

WRITING.TITLE: Suggestion: Work the new solo/dynamic/team stamps into S6 Ranked Reward Borders
WRITING.TEXT:
This year Riot added special markings to signify division in ranked borders, so how about adding something else that signifies the queue preference? Something like three little beads at the top for dynamic, 5 for team, 1 for solo etc, so you can tell how that person earned their rank - by being a good solo player or a good premade player or whatever.
Probably won't further increase toxicity than the stamps themselves will and will allow solo players to feel rewarded for their SOLO achievement. While it won't do anything to improve the solo experience, it sorta helps diversify reward into two ladders (a big complaint is solo players feeling they're being disproportionately rewarded for their play).
Also, aware that people might just try to play the majority of their final 25 games in the season solo to avoid getting a dynamic border but if the player is truly boosted and doesn't belong at that level they will drop in elo over 25 games so it'll still be a more accurate mark of their solo ranking.
Obviously won't apply to bronze but it's not like a solo bronzie is going to feel any worse seeing that other people with premades are also bronze.

When the heck did I call it a cure? I said it was an escape, and there is nothing wrong with using (harmless - compared to other options like self-harm or substance abuse) escapes especially when you're dealing with something for which it feels like there's no cure in sight. The fact of the matter is it's an effective escape meaning a lot of the players are people struggling with that kind of thing, and it's foolish for Riot to implement things that alienate people who are struggling because that's their playerbase. Also I disagree - you can learn to communicate and be decent when socializing without feeling like you have to be part of any sort of consistent group.

I suppose you have a point there. My point with this post was not so much as people NEEDING the rewards, it's more the sense of how people without friends or people to play with are being made to feel like they're less deserving of reward than those that do. It's not a good message to send to a youth fanbase.

^ You can get stomped and still show effort. Contrast this to the SKT vs SUP game, that was also a stomp but you could see SUP were less flippant about it, playing strategically rather than "we didn't practice so we're going to just not try and maybe play for KDA" like G2 were here, even if they were simply outclassed mechanically.
Nah he didn't actually miss a game, they played him (which was funny since they did have Stixxay listed as a sub at the time. Dlift also got a penta that weekend iirc)

Just a fun fact about Kiwikid: on top of all the "anti-records" they mentioned him holding re: most deaths, he actually holds the LCS record for most regular season games being the only player in NA LCS (and only player alongside Yellowstar if you count both EU and NA) to have played in every single *regular season* game, never missing one. Of other players who have played in all splits, Dlift missed a few for CLG's ill-fated S4 korean boot camp and Zion missed a week due to a suspension in S5. He also holds the record for most splits played signed to a single team ([source](http://lol.esportspedia.com/wiki/LCS_Players))

The whole argument that "teams like DIG being in the LCS just makes other teams complacent" is hilarious because one of the things DIG was actually *good* at historically was punishing complacency. You can argue that dig didn't strive for anything beyond mediocrity but how many times did they upset teams who underestimated them? The ol' "dig upset telling another team they need to get their shit together" that happened more than once every split was one of my favorite staples of every season and why I'm sad to see them go. Getting rid of DIG is not going to make NA better. They may have not been a top tier team at any point but they were never a team to just roll over and die to a top team that wasn't trying.

Actually this happened to me too. On OCE and hit G5 at the end of last year, last week over easter break I decided to grind back up and spent a lot of time in s1 where I feel like I equalized my MMR (ended up against mostly s1/g5 players in my non-series games and had ~20lp gains and losses.) When I got to promos however I kept being placed against (and only against, never on my team) high gold or even plat players. And I did promos 4 times before I got into gold thanks to the promo helper giving me two free wins and a lucky afk on the enemy team in a third game. I figured that this type of sudden mmr jump must have just been normal in promos and brushed it off - is it not intentional?

I mean I don't think they're necessarily chronic chokers, both carried Uol in series last year (Hyli was mvp vs SK in spring and Csaci vs Roccat in summer) and never played...this bad when it counted. Looks more to me like the pressure of having to be the backbone this year caught up to them : (. Hopefully it's a one-off that they'll work on for next split.

I feel like I can't call this series just yet. Multiple members of both teams looked sloppy but UoL made the first mistake and it landed OG with a lead on their core player (like the casters remarked Ori and Kindred could do fuck all but keep Zven alive and OG would still take any fight) and that conveniently won them the game. IF next game it's OG who makes the first mistake, I could also see the reverse happen. Looks like the only thing I can call at this point is that it looks like it's going to be a sloppy series.

I'd make a case for Bunny too (technically hasn't been 2 years since his debut on Curse :p) who always looked like a shining mechanical prospect and solid support. Come to think of it, all 5 of my picks for best new NA talents (Hauntzer, Bunny, Dardoch, Matt, Lourlo) played on Curse/Liquid Academy before making it in. Say what you want about Steve's success as an owner, but he probably has the best eye for scouting fresh talent in NA.

Not necessarily true. The top 6 teams in points overall will have a shot at Worlds (2 autoqualify + 4 go to gauntlet). Won't get into the math but barring a very weird situation (where 3+ teams that aren't even in playoffs this split somehow manage to take top playoffs positions next split) the loser of this game will still at least get to run gauntlet provided can make summer playoffs. Of course they'll probably have a low gauntlet seeding, but as C9 proved last year, if they deserve to go to Worlds at that point they ought take the opportunity to prove it.
i played a game with a tahm and the draven head isn't even fit on his model, it's floating on top of his head like a hat only not even touching it - was pretty silly looking.
have to upvote this. got so annoying for me that i ended up just playing ranked (my server doesn't have normal draft) even though i knew i was tired and tilting and^now^i'm^back^on^0lp

WRITING.TITLE: Quinn's new blind mechanic feels 10x more frustrating and oppressive to play against than the old one.
WRITING.TEXT:
Riot removed the old mechanic because they felt it to be a low counterplay frustration feature, but it feels like they replaced it with something that just makes that frustration worse? Previously the blind only stopped you from autoing, the new blind *still* stops you from autoing because unless the Quinn player is an idiot they're not going to remain in your vision range, so you can't click on them. But now you can't even use targeted abilities, aim skillshots, anticipate incoming skillshots or abilities or get a feel for what your team is doing and hers is around you (which arguably makes this one of the most powerful forms of CC as even when you're stunned, you can anticipate what's coming and make decisions as to your next move accordingly)...or do anything really, until it wears off (at least in the case of Graves's smokescreen you can walk out of it unless you are chain cc'd). It's extremely frustrating to play against and I'm not sure what Riot was thinking when they took away the old blind for the reasons stated and then replaced it with this.
I understand that it's in the form of an avoidable skillshot so that exists as counterplay, but the old blind was too so what's Riot's logic in saying that that was unhealthy to the game and this isn't?

The problem is that low elo games tend to be messy bloodfests with a lot of kills because of the way people greed and bloodthirst - it's actually not that hard to stack devourer in low elo by ganking or just playing in the same way a low elo ganking jungler would do. That's why it's so strong in low elo. Best way to balance it would be to remove devourer stacking off kills altogether and make it a purely farm stacking item, enforcing the "farm for your reward, punish the guy for farming by ganking early game" playstyle.

Yeah true, her win rate might go down with duskblade's launch we'll see. I still don't think she's as vulnerable in laning phase as she's said to be though, people who run a defensive summoner and know how to abuse her range and manage the wave won't be overextending or susceptible to ganks too easily unless the enemy can well coordinate dives. In lategame teamfights maybe she can be picked off but the general Lux pattern seems to be to just stand way back and poke until something worthwhile hits. It's hard to get in and assassinate her without it being a 1v5 suicide mission.

WRITING.TITLE: Lux currently feels like old Nidalee to play against.
WRITING.TEXT: You know how they used to say "it doesn't matter how many thousand Qs she misses, it's the one she hits" about Nidalee before they reworked her and she was unanimously considered one of the most obnoxious champions to play against? Same thing goes for Lux right now (this is speaking as someone who both plays against her and abuses the freelo when I do get her) - you can miss all your Qs but the nature of her combo and scaling is that the moment she hits one on you once she's level 6, that's the lane lost, or later in the game, the entire game lost due to the long as hell death timers. She just seems way too low risk high reward right now, hence the high win rate.

Ryze used to be even more braindead than Annie before the rework, all his abilities being targetted. That said she still would have been a better choice since learning how to burst and fire at least some skillshots is the core of playing pretty much any mage.
Cull is the biggest giveaway noob trap right now. Deathcap is still one for mages, especially in a resistance stacking heavy meta.

I actually recall reading something in a visual design class about how the spacing in comic sans was also specifically designed to be easily digestable by kids, or even older people, with dyslexia so there's that too.

Yeah I wasn't trying to imply he was the worst member of the team, just the least remarked upon. Keane did perform worse but people talked about him more because his anti-carry cheese schtick made him unique.
Oh hurr didn't know which spelling the idiom used, thanks man.

His storyline is a fucking awesome underdog narrative, could be a movie plot, if you read it from start til now. He was bouncing around challenger for a couple of seasons before Curse Academy picked him up at the *last second* for the expansion tournament (a one-off qualifier mind you) to replace Cris after they failed to defeat CLG (by one game) in the relegation tournament. Rule changes then meant that CA had to be sold to an organization with minimal infrastructure, and while Gravity did decently all things given Hauntzer was generally regarded as the [worst top laner NA](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CJwsYB_UMAAWyLL.jpg:large) after his first split. In summer his team did better (only to come to a crashing fall) but he was overshadowed by teammates and generally only remarked upon for whiffing some clutch ults. But one person did notice the diamond in the rough, none other than someone he admired a lot - NA's most stalwart, but fading veteran Dyrus who just so happened to need a replacement and that's how Hauntzer found himself on NA's most iconic and arguably most successful team, a move that was met with a lot of negativity especially given aside from him TSM had assembled an all-star lineup. And now we've got this, the guy is possibly the best member of the team so far this season. Honestly you can't ask for a better script.

While both can work it feels like the team (SKT) approach is better in the long run. Look what's happened to C9 and to a lesser extent FNC when the designated shotcaller has been taken out of the mix.
Wasn't here for S3 so out of curiosity, what was the assassin trio? I'm guessing Zed, Kha and someone else?

There are a handful of characters who have gay undertones in their interaction and lore, and can easily be interpreted as such, Diana/Leona (this one I believe IronStylus even outright confirmed Diana was in love with Leona in an AMA iirc), Vi/Cait ("Cupcake"), the latest story about TF/Graves was pretty gay (or I, a straight man mind you, interpreted it as such, and yes I know TF was previously with Evelynn but it's completely possible for someone to be be attracted to both sexes and that's even less represented).
Shut down used to feel more satisfying but now it plays for any guy whos picked up two consecutive kills it feels meaningless.

WRITING.TITLE: With the new champ select, being "first pick" will be the least desirable position.
WRITING.TEXT:
Note, this isn't a complaint thread, just me noting what will be an interesting shift from the current state of things where getting stuck being last pick repeatedly is generally the least desired position.
Going into the new champ select, Riot decided to give the bans to the last three picks (3, 4, 5) with the intention of making champ select fairer but thinking about it, with how roles are now going to be decided before anyone even enters champ select there's no longer going to be much advantage to being an early pick in ranked - first pick no longer gives you the benefit of role selection (as you'd have already chosen your role) or bans and instead the earlier you pick the more likely you're forced to blind pick your matchup and are going to end up getting countered. The only advantage I can think of is you may get a chance to first pick an OP champ but this is something I rarely see done in solo queue at present and people tend to just ban away OPs anyway.

You're still delaying your powerspike somewhat going for hydra over ghostblade, on a champion like Zed who thrives on getting fed off his mid-game spike you don't want to sacrifice that just to get some lifesteal.

Depends on the person. For some people it passes on its own, for some it passes with therapy and treatment (which in itself varies from person to person. As he said maybe the meds/psychiatrists he's seen weren't right for him, and there's one that'll work out for him out there), for some it just never gets better and lasts forever. For some once it's gone it's gone, for others it goes for a bit and then comes back. But regardless (and this is speaking as someone who did suffer it in high school and from talking to others who've been through the same) when you have depression you genuinely feel like it's going to be there forever.
Mid lane: When my enemy laner roams and I ward his tracks and ping his ass but that overextending bot lane still blames me for not following Talon with mobis from base.

The synergy issue might also be a 'shoved together this roster with like a week's notice' problem too (CLG have had HuHi and Stixxay around all season even if not playing, TSM is in a similar boat admittedly but at least the management was always aware the team would be attending IEM and as you mentioned, the infrastructure is better). UoL still have the whole break to get it together - hopefully the management can work out those kinks. I want them to succeed : (

UoL were at least playing a little better the second time. I always liked the team because they seemed a good natured lovable organization and while the first game was disappointing I'm not going to worry just yet because they showed a bit of improvement between the games and honestly they were invited at the last minute and probably put together this roster/had to switch back to practicing on this patch on just as short notice. At least Hyli/Gillius/Vici are showing a propensity to make plays (need to learn to do it in a way that doesn't mean overextending and dying though. That's a teamplay problem they should work on). Hopefully Fox and Steelback can wake up (I know they were...better in spring split) and the team spends the break working on establishing an actual shotcalling system (they don't have the raw talent to just rely on brute force 'chaos style' anymore) and get it together. I believe in Unicorns.

Oh, yeah I wasn't trying to rush to any conclusions, by 'has the cards' I meant he has all the attributes of a solid top laner (not afraid to go for plays when he sees the opportunity, good laner (showing good lane mechanics vs Acorn/Flame individually have little to do with LGD as a team), not reckless, good map awareness and teamplayer) which if he keeps it up, has the potential to hold up internationally. Maybe that wasn't clear haha.

He *was* Dyrus style in that he did exactly everything his team needed him to at all times - he didn't try to be a primary carry or play forward in a way that felt like he had a 'got the team on my shoulders' mentality, he did what he had to for the team. But the difference was he is still proactive and when an opportunity to make an outplay surfaces, he sees it and takes it. He has a great mentality and the fact that he held onto it despite being the only player in that game with 0 international experience is huge! I'm glad to say NA may finally have a top laner who has all the cards to hold a candle to KR ones.

Given he's the only guy here without any international experience, Hauntzer is playing really solidly, not afraid to go for the outplays but not going recklessly ham either - good mentality. Very impressed.

How does ingame elo have anything to do with whether people vote along the lines of their favorite players or the most skilled players? That's just a personal preference, you can be bronze (or not even have an interest in playing ranked yourself) and still be interested in seeing high level plays, or you could be Diamond and a lot of your interest in the game is thanks to one personality (irrespective of his skill) and you want to see him at the event. Nice shitpost/10.

In his prime he was fun to watch, I hope he manages to regain his form. Hoping this was maybe just a bad meta for him/inexperience choking.
